System Design Interviews

  • Created : June, 04, 2020
  • Last Updated: June, 04, 2020

A good performance in these interviews always helps in bagging a good offer in terms of pay.

What is a System Design Interview ?

A system design interview is a technical interview that lays lot of emphasis on the aspects of system design like – how its built, what’s the architecture, what's the data model like etc. These interviews are hard and require lot of practice and work on different technologies. Also these interviews are very different from a typical data structure or algorithm interview where you are given a problem and asked to write a program for it.

In this type of interview you are asked to design a system or application from scratch. They usually last for around 45 minutes or an hour. They involve a broad set of knowledge. Involve concepts of scalability, availability and sometime security.

On the second image shown below you can see their budget categorized into different categories. So we know how much we spent on groceries and if we are near to our budget or not.

Please checkout mint.com if you have not used it earlier. It will help you understand what the app does.

Scope

Let's now try to scope the important features that we can base our design on. It is almost impossible to build a complete solution in a span of an hour or less. So concentrating on the key features is important.

Some of the key features could be :

  • Registering a new user.
  • User provides their accounts
  • Connecting to the banks website using the users account details.
  • Downloading users transaction history - maybe last weeks, last months or last 6 months.
  • Writing programs to categorize these transactions into categories like groceries, travel, house etc.
  • Helping user create a budget around these categories e.g. User can set a limit of say 200$ on groceries.
  • Generating alerts / notifications on going out of budget
  • Scaling the system to millions of users

      • The figure shown below outlines the scope discussed above.

        Non Functional Requirements

        Some non functional requirements could be :

        • High Availability : The site should be up 24/7.
        • High Scalability : The system should scale to millions of users.

          Out of Scope

          There is limited time in these interviews and we cannot entirely cover the entire set of details :

          • Any UI work, we will not be covering UI design in this case study
          • User Registeration and User Login (authorization/authentication is out of scope)
          • Machine Learning Layer for building recommendations to users

            Database Design

            Let's start with the database design. Its ok to use the relational database as relational databases can easily support upto millions of users in the database. Apart from these the support they provide for ACID transactions is excellent. There would be some methods where inserting / updating records in the database we would require ACID transaction support.

            There would be huge amount of transaction per user.

            Storing the transaction data in relational database doesnot make sense as the quantity of data could be huge and it can be in various formats.

            A big data approach seems to be a good fit. So data can be pulled and dropped in HDFS or Amazon S3 in temporary storage or bucket. Some programs can then act on that data like Apache Spark programs, cleanse it and then put the cleaned data in a NoSQL database like cassandra. Further calculation on data like the one that calculates the current spendings of the user can then be stored in the relational database or nosql database itself.

            Some of the key tables that come to our mind are shown below

            • High Availability : The site should be up 24/7.
            • High Scalability : The system should scale to millions of users.

            More info on these tables

            • User : This table stores the users information
            • Account : Stores info on the bank accounts the user has
            • Budget : Stores the users budget. For e.g if the user has kept 300$ limit for grocery in a month, this value is stored in this table
            • Transaction : Even though we expect to store transaction data in big data storage, we just showed the table here to depict the columns it can have
            • Category : this table has the list of categories defined for e.g grocery, travel, food (eating out), gas, house rent etc
            • Merchant : This table contains the list of merchants that can be present on at transaction e.g walmart, cvs pharmacy, SHELL etc.
            • MerchantCategory : This table contains the list of merchants that can be present on a transaction e.g walmart, cvs pharmacy, SHELL etc. Based on this spendings for a particular category can be calculated. So if you have 2 transaction say for 10 and 20 dollars with merchant as 'SHELL'. Then we know the user spending 10 + 20 = 30$ on gasoline

              High level design

              To build the high level design of this system first we will try to visualize how we can break each feature into software components i.e. services, batch jobs, rules etc. At the end of the day we are trying to build a website that sits on top of cleaned data , is highly available and generates notification or alerts for the users. This cleaned data for the website is the data that is pulled from the users transactions available in his bank account data.
              We need a service that takes input for user account details and stores this info in the database. This service can connect to the bank account on behalf of user and can allow manual refresh of transaction data. We will call this service has AccountService We will need another service for showing the Budget details of the user i.e what are the current stats on his budge. We will call this service as ShowBudgetService and it would provide details in json to show the current status of users budge. So it will have things like how much the user is spending on groceries and how much is his total budget on that. Another service could be which will allow the user to create a budget , so we can show a template of a budget for e.g some prefilled template and the user can then customize it according to his needs. So can keep amounts specifically for different categories. We can store this budget using the BudgetService. The diagram shown below shows the high level design for our approach for building this system
